ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I can read hieroglyphs now  how many other people can say the same?
Builds on EGYP 110. You complete the rest of the basic grammar concepts in the first half of the semester then spend the second half applying what you learned to real texts.
Learned more Egyptian grammar, especially verbal forms, and got practice with translation.
I furthered my grammar and transliteration and translation skills from L1 and learned how to apply these skills to decoding ancient Egyptian texts and artifacts

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Zhang presents the language and grammar of Middle Egyptian in a clear and accessible way. The first half of the course studying the grammar was well-paced and engaging. The second half, however, I thought was a little slow. Assessments were also too infrequent to keep me accountable for staying sharp on the grammar and vocab.

Strengths: Very good instructor who supports students in need of help.
Weaknesses: Assignments sometimes prioritize quantity over understanding of material. Pace was at times too quick.
Love the content hate the format
I really appreciated the second half of the semester and all the work we did with actual translationsit really helped solidify the main concepts

The lectures and practice with grammar was great. The translation work on Shipwrecked Sailor was enjoyable although the group work was sometimes unnecessary since usually many people hadn't done the homework. The emphasis on parsing and understanding verbal forms was very useful for Egyptian. I think it would have been useful to have more structure to learning vocabulary. I think by the end of the class, vocabulary was definitely the main obstacle for translation. The Met trip was certainly worth it because it was great to see the hard work of the semester pay off by being able to translate a specific object, and to some extent to sight read, especially the htp-dj-nswt formulas, and also to see the language more in its historical context and how that changed over time. The class as a whole was very well organized in Canvas. It was always easy to see what the topics would be or what the homework is.

This course was great. It was organized in a way that made learning this very difficult ancient language largely approachable and it was always a fairly interesting course. All the assessments were fair and were as expected. It was really cool to learn how to decode ancient texts and artifacts. I don't really think there were any real weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes reading hieroglyphs is super fun!
I would recommend this course if you want to learn Middle Egyptian.
Yes if the hate language but need a credit
Yes! I struggled a bit in EGYP 110, but felt much more comfortable with the concepts this semester.

Yes, if you're in need of language credits this is a very approachable course and when are you ever going to get another chance to learn Egyptian hieroglyphics? Also, if you're very interested in ancient Egyptian archeology this is just the course for you.
